title: The iconic London eye rotates BACKWARDS for the first time in its 20-year history
text:
The London Eye has rotated backwards for the first time in its 20-year history today - to mark the clocks going backwards this weekend.

The huge Southbank attraction changed its direction for one hour, starting at around 7.30am, with special guests stepping on board to receive a new perspective of the London skyline.

But while the moment was televised live on ITV, it was less about the spectacle and more to serve as a reminder that everyone gains an hour back at 2am in the morning.

The change between British Summer Time and Greenwich Mean Time has been going on every year since 1916 when the Summer Time Act was passed by Parliament, although at that point the time changed by 80 minutes over a period of four weeks.

The practice of changing the clocks is designed to make evening daylight last longer, but sacrifices normal sunrise times.

Since 2001 the timings for daylight savings have been aligned across European Union countries, however this might be about to change.

In March, the European Parliament voted to scrap the twice-a-year custom of changing the clocks by 2021, leaving national governments to now give their assent.

The change will apply to the UK if it stays in the EU, leading some to coin the term Cloxit in a case where Britain loses daylight savings.

The huge Southbank attraction changed its direction for one hour, starting at around 7.30am, with special guests stepping on board to receive a new perspective of the London skyline

Member states will be able to choose whether to remain on 'permanent summer' or 'permanent winter' time under the draft directive, which passed by 410 votes to 192.

Tory MEPs, who voted against the proposal, reacted angrily to the development, with one accusing the European commission of acting like 'time lords', according to the Guardian.

However if the UK leaves the EU before 2021 then Westminster would be free to choose to keep daylight savings, or move to a different system altogether.

John Flack, the Conservative MEP for the East of England, said: 'We’ve long been aware the EU wants too much control over our lives – now they want to control time itself.

The European Parliament has voted to scrap daylight savings time across the EU, with countries choosing to move to 'permanent Winter' or 'Summer' time

'You would think they had other things to worry about without wanting to become time lords.'

The idea behind the scrapping of DST came from a survey launched by the Parliament which 'showed a large majority in favour' of abolishing DST.

However the online survey only had 4.6m participants from across Europe - three million of them German, who dominated the pro-abolition camp.

In Britain just 13,000 people bothered to vote. In total, around 80 per cent of respondents wanted to abolish DST.

In 2012, a bill to trial a three-year period of continuous British was abandoned because Parliament ran out of time to debate it.

The suggestion was however opposed in Scotland and Northern England because it would leave most areas dark until 10am in Winter.

It would make farmers’ lives harder and increase road accidents, critics said. This continues to be the most powerful argument against changing current practice.
description: The huge attraction on London's Southbank changed its direction for the first time in its 20-year history for one hour to mark the clocks going back on Sunday.
